info.game_comments:
2002 College Championship semifinal game 3.
From the Schottenstein Center at the Ohio State University in Columbus.

(1, 1).clue: The viceroy butterfly looking like the monarch is:(A) mimicry(B) puppetry(C) chicory(D) rabbitry

(2, 1).clue: This founding member of Destiny's Child tells people that her first name rhymes with fiance

(3, 1).clue: Try mixing lipstick with petroleum jelly if you run out of this cheek cosmetic

(4, 1).clue: In 1902 he published his newest Sherlock Holmes tale, "The Hound of the Baskervilles"

(5, 1).clue: This term for a stingerless male bee sounds like an unmanned spy plane

(6, 1).clue: Cards for these are air-blown into magazines

(1, 2).clue: The only hormone that can lower blood sugar is:(A) epinephrine(B) glucagon(C) thyroxine(D) insulin

(2, 2).clue: In 2001 Elton John courted controversy when he sang a duet with this rapper at the Grammys

(3, 2).clue: Make sure to avoid the eye area when you apply this insect sweet that's Heloise's favorite facial

(4, 2).clue: When Cecil Rhodes died in 1902, his fortune went to establishing scholarships to this school

(5, 2).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew reports from the Monkey River in Belize)  A mainstay of the toucan's diet, it's also in the name of the cereal that it promotes

(6, 2).clue: You don't have to be a detective to know that this math process involves deduction

(1, 3).clue: A Venus's Flytrap is considered:(A) aluminous(B) bigamous(C) carnivorous(D) decamerous

(2, 3).clue: On July 30, 2002 he gave a rare live TV appearance, broadcast from Asbury Park, New Jersey on the "Today" show

(3, 3).clue: Add a half pound of the "sea" type of this to your bath water & you may feel like you're swimming in Utah

(4, 3).clue: He & Matthew Henson made their first serious attempt to reach the North Pole, but it would take 7 more years

(5, 3).clue: This substance produced by bees is used in the making of candles & cosmetics

(6, 3).clue: In 2000 the Yankees & the Mets played in a World Series dubbed this

(1, 4).clue: Gills are not a feature on:(A) manatees(B) sharks(C) mushrooms(D) sand dollars

(2, 4).clue: In 2002 she delivered a new album, "Full Moon", a baby, Sy'rai, & an MTV reality series on her life

(3, 4).clue: This sandwich spread is Heloise's favorite oil treatment for the hair, but use it only on the ends

(4, 4).clue: After 3 years of fighting, this South African war came to an end

(5, 4).clue: Ectopistes migratorius is the scientific name of this now extinct variety of pigeon

(6, 4).clue: It's a government payment to a farmer not to grow something

(1, 5).clue: Experiencing piloerection you have:(A) hemorrhoids(B) razor stubble(C) goose bumps(D) bed hair

(2, 5).clue: The parents of this R&B songstress named her in tribute to Mahatma Gandhi -- she was due on his birthday

(3, 5).clue: Cut this kitchen item into wedges for applying makeup or for separating your toes during a pedicure

(4, 5).clue: In August this "Junior", son of a physician, poet & essayist, was appointed to the Supreme Court

(5, 5).clue: Seen here, this long-winged native of the Andes Mountains is actually a type of vulture

(6, 5).clue: Adjective for something that lives under your skin, like a parasite

(1, 1).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew reports in front of the Santa Maria in Columbus)  On October 12, 1492 Santa Maria sailor Rodrigo de Triana did this first, but Columbus awarded himself the prize for it, anyway

(2, 1).clue: In 1998 this school's Trojans defeated Arizona State 21-14 in the College World Series' highest-scoring final game

(3, 1).clue: In 1949 the state legislature made this "wily" canine South Dakota's state animal

(4, 1).clue: There must be "2001" reasons to read this Englishman's sci-fi classic "Childhood's End"

(5, 1).clue: Sharing the 1945 Nobel Prize with Alexander Fleming, Howard Florey & Ernst Chain developed this antibiotic drug

(6, 1).clue: It's the informal, more common term for rhinoplasty

(1, 2).clue: The first thing Columbus noted in his log about the New World natives was their lack of these

(2, 2).clue: In 1947 NYU's Abraham Balk became the only man to win the foil & epee events in this sport in the same year

(3, 2).clue: This South Dakota capital was founded as a fort in the early 1800s & named for a French fur trader

(4, 2).clue: Reinaldo Arenas called "Journey to" this Cuban city "A Novel in Three Trips"

(5, 2).clue: 2 basic drug categories are depressants & these, which include caffeine

(6, 2).clue: We predict you'll know that this man famous for his prophecies was court physician to King Charles IX of France

(1, 3).clue: After 7 years living in this country, Columbus asked its King John II for backing, but was turned down

(2, 3).clue: The U. of Nebraska has had 3 Heisman Trophy winners: Johnny Rodgers, Mike Rozier & this quarterback in 2001

(3, 3).clue: South Dakota's highest point is 7,242-foot-high Harney Peak in these hills

(4, 3).clue: The Awangarda Krakowska was an avant-garde literary movement begun in this country in 1922

(5, 3).clue: The name of this anti-inflammatory drug used in OTC preparations is a contraction of isobutylphenyl propionic acid

(6, 3).clue: Canada's Cape Breton Island forms part of this province

(1, 4).clue: This settlement Columbus named for its Christmas founding wasn't "feliz" when all its men were killed

(2, 4).clue: On March 13, 1981 this future Olympian set an NCAA indoor record in the long jump by leaping 27' 10"

(3, 4).clue: A majority leader of the U.S. Senate, this South Dakotan was the first in his family to graduate from college

(4, 4).clue: A priest falls for the girl he's sent to exorcise in "Of Love and Other Demons" by this Colombian Nobel Prize-winner

(5, 4).clue: Also called methylmorphine, this opium-derived drug is used in some cough medicines

(6, 4).clue: A mutual fund that doesn't carry a sales charge going in or out is described as this type

(1, 5).clue: (Sofia of the Clue Crew reports on the deck of the Santa Maria in Columbus.)  Chris thought he was in Asia because he thought the length of one of these at the equator was 57 miles, not 69

(2, 5).clue: In 1994 Amy Van Dyken set an NCAA record, 21.77 sec., in the shortest freestyle swimming distance, this many yards

(3, 5).clue: A pageant inspired by her "Little House" books takes place in De Smet in late June & early July

(4, 5).clue: "The Diary of a Superfluous Man" is a poignant novella by this Russian author of "Fathers and Sons"

(5, 5).clue: Used today as an antispasmodic asthma treatment, this drug's name is Italian for "beautiful woman"

(6, 5).clue: It's John Donne's famous 5-word phrase about isolation that precedes "entire of itself"

(0, 0).clue: Baptist minister Francis Bellamy penned this oath in 1892 to reflect his Christian Socialist beliefs
